nodes.text: The Japanese original shall prevail over the English translation in case of inconsistency
Clinical trials must comply with Good Clinical Practice (GCP) standards
Sponsors must prepare clinical trials according to specified standards
Sponsor-investigators must prepare trials according to specified standards
The ordinance applies to drugs as defined in the Pharmaceutical Affairs Act
Clinical trials must adhere to standards for management by sponsors
Clinical trials must adhere to standards for management by sponsor-investigators
An Institutional Review Board must be established for clinical trials
Medical institutions conducting trials must meet specified standards
Investigators conducting trials must meet specified standards
Informed consent must be obtained from trial subjects
Specific documents must be submitted for reexamination of trials
Clinical trials must ensure scientific quality
Clinical trials must ensure reliability of data
Clinical trials must protect rights of human subjects
Clinical trials must protect safety of human subjects
Clinical trials must protect welfare of human subjects
Investigators must be physicians or dentists
Investigators must supervise clinical trial activities at medical institutions
A 'test drug' is a drug product tested in a clinical trial or post-marketing clinical study
A 'comparator' is used as a reference for comparison with a test drug
'Investigational products' include the test drug and comparator used in a clinical trial
'Post-marketing clinical study drug' includes the test drug and comparator used in a post-marketing study
'Drug used in clinical trial' includes the test drug and drugs to evaluate its efficacy and safety
'Drug, etc. used in clinical trial' includes drugs with the same active ingredients as trial drugs
A subject/trial subject receives an investigational product or post-marketing clinical study drug
A subject/trial subject may participate as a control in a clinical trial
Source documents must include data from administration of investigational products to subjects
Source documents must include records of medical treatment of subjects in the clinical trial
A subinvestigator must be a physician or dentist
A subinvestigator takes charge of part of the clinical trial activities under the investigator's supervision
A post-marketing clinical study subinvestigator must be a physician or dentist
Case report forms must contain source data on each trial subject
Case report forms must contain evaluation of subject data by investigator or subinvestigator
Clinical research coordinators must be healthcare professionals
Clinical research coordinators must work under supervision of investigator or subinvestigator
Post-marketing clinical research coordinators must be healthcare professionals
Coordinating investigator must be a physician or dentist
Coordinating investigator duties include interpreting protocol at relevant medical institutions
A coordinating committee must be composed of multiple physicians or dentists
The sponsor or sponsor-investigator must assign coordination duties to the coordinating committee
Monitoring must oversee the progress of a clinical trial or post-marketing clinical study
Monitoring must determine compliance with the Ministerial Ordinance and protocol
Monitoring must be performed on medical institutions by the sponsor or appointed individual
Monitoring must ensure the clinical trial or post-marketing study is properly conducted
Audits must examine trial-related activities for compliance with regulations and protocols
Audits must be performed by the sponsor or an appointed individual
Adverse events include any disease or clinical signs occurring in treated subjects
A legally acceptable representative may be a parent, spouse, guardian or similar person
A sponsor-investigator must be a physician or dentist
Sponsor-investigators must submit a clinical trial notification to conduct a trial
A coordinating investigator must submit clinical trial notification on behalf of all participating investigators
A sponsor-investigator must submit clinical trial notification to conduct a trial at their institution
An investigational product provider must supply investigational products to sponsor-investigators
Expanded clinical trials should be conducted with humanitarian perspective
Documents specified in Article 14 must be submitted for drug clinical trial applications
Collect and generate relevant data in compliance with specified chapters and sections of the Act
Prepare written operating procedures for duties related to sponsoring and managing clinical trials
Include protocol preparation in written operating procedures
Include selection of medical institutions and investigators in operating procedures
Include control and accountability of drugs used in clinical trials in operating procedures
Include collection of adverse drug reaction information in operating procedures
Sponsors shall secure professionals with adequate expertise to fulfill clinical trial duties
Sponsors shall complete studies on quality, toxicity and pharmacological effects of the test drug
Sponsors shall select medical institutions meeting qualifications in Article 35
Sponsors shall select investigators meeting qualifications in Article 42
Sponsors shall prepare a clinical trial protocol
Protocol should include name and address of trial sponsor
Include name and country of residence for persons outside Japan in clinical trial documentation
Provide name and address of in-country representative for non-Japanese residents
Document name, address, and scope of duties for any outsourced clinical trial activities
Include names and addresses of medical institutions in clinical trial documentation
List names and titles of appointed investigators in clinical trial documentation
State clinical trial objectives in documentation
Provide summary of drug used in clinical trial
Include clinical trial design in documentation
Protocol must state reasons for enrolling subjects who cannot give consent
Protocol should explain how subject disadvantages are minimized
Protocol must state if subjects unable to consent will be enrolled
Protocol should explain intent to seek marketing approval for emergency use
Protocol should explain current treatments are likely insufficient
Protocol should explain possibility of saving subject's life with test drug
Protocol must note establishment of Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee
Sponsors shall gain agreement with investigators on protocol content
Sponsors shall gain agreement with investigators on protocol compliance
Sponsors shall revise protocols when important new information becomes available
Sponsors shall prepare an Investigator's Brochure with specified information
The Investigator's Brochure shall include the chemical name/ID of the test drug
The Investigator's Brochure shall include quality, toxicity and effects of the test drug
The Investigator's Brochure shall include results of any clinical studies of the test drug
Sponsors shall revise the Investigator's Brochure when important new information becomes available
Sponsors must request investigators to prepare written information for subject explanation
Sponsors must submit the protocol to the head of the medical institution before the trial
Sponsors must submit the Investigator's Brochure to the head of the medical institution before the trial
Sponsors must submit a sample case report form to the head of the medical institution before the trial
Sponsors must submit a list of prospective investigators to the head of the medical institution before the trial
Sponsors must submit documents on trial expense burden to the head of the medical institution before the trial
Sponsors must submit documents on subject injury compensation to the head of the medical institution before the trial
Sponsors may submit documents via electronic means with consent of the medical institution head
Electronic submission must use specified electromagnetic means
Electronic submission requires computers connected via telecommunication line
Information must be transmitted from sponsor's computer to medical institution's computer
Transmitted information must be recorded in a file on the recipient's computer
Sponsors may make information accessible to medical institution head via computer file
Sponsors must notify medical institutions of their decision to accept electronic document transmission
Electronic documents must be securely stored on magnetic disk, CD-ROM, or other storage media
Medical institutions must be able to print out electronically stored data
Sponsors must inform medical institutions of the type and description of electronic means used
Sponsors must obtain written or electronic consent from medical institutions for electronic communication
Sponsors must specify the file format used for electronic communication
Sponsors must cease electronic communication if notified of its unacceptability by medical institutions
Do not submit documents electronically without consent from medical institution head
Do not supply investigational products before clinical trial contract is concluded
Conclude a written contract when outsourcing clinical trial duties
Specify scope of outsourced duties in contract
Describe operating procedures for outsourced duties in contract
State sponsor's right to verify outsourced duties are conducted properly
Describe instructions to contractor in outsourcing contract
Contractor must submit reports to the clinical trial sponsor
Contract must describe measures relating to outsourced duties
Contract may be concluded using electronic means instead of written form
Contractor must consent to use of electronic contract
Electronic contract must use connected computer systems
Electronic contract information must be transmitted via telecommunication line
Electronic contract information must be recorded in a computer file
Sponsor must make trial information accessible to contractor via computer file
Contractor must record trial information in their computer file
Trial information may be delivered via secure storage media
Information sharing method must allow printing of recorded data
Method must confirm information has not been modified
Sponsor shall inform contractor before concluding contract
Sponsors must obtain consent from contractors for using electromagnetic means
Sponsors must notify contractors of the type and description of electromagnetic means to be used
Sponsors shall not use electromagnetic means if the contractor notifies them it is unacceptable
Clinical trial contracts must be concluded in writing between sponsors and medical institutions
Clinical trial contracts must specify the date of conclusion
Clinical trial contracts must specify the name and address of the sponsor
Clinical trial contracts must specify names and addresses of contractors if duties are outsourced
The contract must specify the name(s) and address(es) of the medical institution(s)
The contract must specify the name(s) and title(s) of the person(s) in charge from each party
The contract must specify the name(s) of the investigator(s)
The contract must specify the duration of the clinical trial
The contract must describe the control/accountability of drugs used in the trial
The contract must describe record and data keeping procedures
The contract must describe how subject confidentiality will be maintained
The contract must describe compensation for trial-related injuries to subjects
Sponsors must take necessary measures like purchasing insurance to compensate subjects for trial-related injuries
Sponsors must take compensation measures before starting the clinical trial
Foreign sponsors must appoint an in-country representative in Japan
The in-country representative must reside in Japan
The in-country representative must be eligible to sponsor clinical trials
The in-country representative must conduct procedures for sponsoring the trial on behalf of the foreign sponsor
The in-country representative must take measures to prevent health hazards from trial drugs
Prepare written operating procedures for duties related to preparing and managing clinical trials
Secure professionals with adequate expertise to fulfill trial preparation and management duties
Complete studies on quality, toxicity and pharmacological effects of the test drug before trial
Prepare a protocol including sponsor-investigator name and address
Include contractor name, address and scope of outsourced duties in protocol if applicable
Include names and addresses of medical institutions in the protocol
The protocol must state the objectives of the clinical trial
The protocol must include a summary of the drug used in the trial
The protocol must state the name and address of the investigational product provider
The protocol must describe the clinical trial design
The protocol must describe subject selection criteria
The protocol must describe direct access to source documents
The protocol must describe record and data keeping procedures
The protocol should name coordinators assigned responsibilities, if applicable
Protocol should explain intent to submit application for marketing approval of test drug for emergency use
Protocol should explain current treatments are unlikely to achieve sufficient effects for subject
Protocol should explain sufficient possibility of saving subject's life by using test drug
Protocol should note establishment of Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee
Sponsor-investigator shall revise protocol when important new information becomes available
Sponsor-investigator shall prepare an Investigator's Brochure with specified information
The Investigator's Brochure must include the chemical name or identification code of the test drug
The Investigator's Brochure must include quality, toxicity, and pharmacological effects of the test drug
The Investigator's Brochure must include results of any clinical studies conducted on the test drug
The sponsor-investigator shall revise the Investigator's Brochure when important new information becomes available
The sponsor-investigator shall prepare written information for the clinical trial
The sponsor-investigator shall submit required documents to the head of the medical institution for approval
The sponsor-investigator shall submit the protocol and its amendments to the medical institution head
The sponsor-investigator shall submit written operating procedures for monitoring to the medical institution head
Sponsor-investigator must have an audit plan for related duties
Sponsor-investigator must maintain a list of prospective subinvestigators
Document control/accountability of drugs used in the clinical trial
Document notifications given by sponsor-investigator per Ministerial Ordinance
Document compensation to subjects for trial-related injuries
Medical institution must provide sponsor-investigator access to records upon request
Sponsor-investigator may terminate trial if institution violates ordinance or protocol
Contract with contractor must specify scope of outsourced duties
Contract must describe operating procedures for outsourced duties
Contract must state sponsor's right to ascertain performance of duties
Contract must describe instructions given to the contractor
Contract must state sponsor's right to verify compliance with instructions
Contract must describe reporting requirements from contractor to sponsor
Sponsor-investigator shall take necessary measures for subject compensation
Sponsors must purchase insurance to compensate subjects for trial-related injuries
Sponsors shall label investigational product containers with 'For clinical trial use only'
Sponsors shall include their name and address on investigational product labels
Sponsors outside Japan shall include country name on investigational product labels
Sponsors shall include chemical name or ID code on investigational product labels
Sponsors shall include manufacturing number/code on investigational product labels
Sponsors shall include storage and expiration info on labels if necessary
Sponsors must enable identification of test drug from comparator in emergencies
Investigational products must be packaged to prevent contamination during transport
Investigational products must be packaged to prevent deterioration during storage
Sponsors shall retain records of investigational product manufacturing
Sponsors shall retain records of drug supply and retrieval for each medical institution
Sponsors shall retain records of disposal of drugs used in clinical trials
Sponsors shall prepare written procedures for drug control at medical institutions
Sponsor shall prepare documents explaining reconstitution procedures for investigational products
Sponsor shall deliver reconstitution procedure documents to investigators and other specified staff
Sponsor shall supply investigational products manufactured at adequately equipped sites
Manufacturing sites must have adequate buildings to ensure investigational product quality
Sponsor shall deliver operating procedures to medical institutions without delay
Sponsors may select drugs for expanded clinical trials from medical institution stocks
Sponsors shall indicate required information on investigational product containers in Japanese
Investigational product storage managers must manage products separately from other drugs
Sponsors shall prepare a document describing duties assigned to coordinating investigators
Sponsors may establish an Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee
The Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee may deliberate on continuing ongoing trials
The Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee may deliberate on protocol revisions
Sponsor shall prepare written operating procedures for Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee deliberation
Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee must conduct deliberation in compliance with procedures
Sponsor shall prepare and retain records of committee deliberation
Sponsor shall collect information on quality, efficacy and safety of trial drug
Sponsor shall provide collected drug information to heads of medical institutions
Sponsor shall notify investigators of specified events annually within 3 months after each 1-year period
Sponsor shall notify medical institution heads of specified events annually within 3 months after each 1-year period
Sponsors shall immediately notify investigators and medical institution heads of relevant facts
Sponsors shall revise protocols and Investigator's Brochure when aware of relevant new information
Sponsors shall obtain investigator consent for protocol revisions
Sponsors shall prepare written operating procedures for monitoring
Monitoring shall be conducted by visiting medical institutions
Monitors shall immediately notify investigators of non-compliance issues
Monitors shall submit a monitoring report after each visit or communication
Sponsors must prepare an audit plan for clinical trials
Sponsors shall prepare written operating procedures for audit-related duties
Audits must be conducted according to the audit plan and operating procedures
Auditors must be independent of drug development and monitoring divisions
Auditors shall prepare an audit report documenting the audit findings
Auditors must submit an audit certificate verifying the audit has been conducted
Sponsors shall cancel contracts with medical institutions violating regulations or protocols
Sponsors must promptly notify if a clinical trial is suspended or prematurely terminated
Sponsor must notify medical institutions in writing of clinical trial suspension or termination reasons
Sponsor must notify medical institutions if clinical data won't be included in regulatory application
Sponsor must provide reason for excluding clinical data from regulatory application
Sponsor must prepare clinical trial reports upon trial completion or termination
Sponsor must retain clinical trial records until marketing approval or later date
Sponsors must retain protocol documents for 3 years after trial completion or termination
Sponsors must retain clinical trial reports for 3 years after trial completion or termination
Sponsors must retain case report forms for 3 years after trial completion or termination
Sponsors must retain monitoring and audit records for 3 years after trial completion or termination
Sponsors outside Japan must have in-country representative retain specified records
Sponsor-investigators must control and account for investigational products used in trials
Indicate 'For clinical trial use only' on investigational product containers/packages in Japanese
Include sponsor-investigator name and address on investigational product containers/packages
Include chemical name or ID code on investigational product containers/packages
Include manufacturing number/code on investigational product containers/packages
Include storage and expiration info on containers/packages if necessary
Do not include proposed brand name on investigational products or packaging
Enable subinvestigators to identify test drug from comparator in emergencies
Prevent contamination and deterioration of investigational products during transport and storage
Prepare records of investigational product manufacturing, including date, method, quantity, and quality tests
Record quantity and date of obtaining or receiving drugs used in the clinical trial
Maintain records of disposal of drugs used in the clinical trial
Prepare written procedures for drug control/accountability at the medical institution
Deliver drug control procedures to medical institution after trial approval
Prepare documents explaining investigational product handling procedures as needed
Deliver product handling documents to subinvestigators, coordinators, and storage managers
Investigational products must be manufactured at sites with adequate buildings and facilities
Manufacturing sites must have appropriate manufacturing control systems
Manufacturing sites must have appropriate quality control systems
For expanded trials, drugs may be selected from medical institution stocks
Investigational product containers must be labeled in Japanese with required information
Investigational products must be managed separately from other drugs
Sponsor-investigator may assign coordination duties to a coordinating investigator or committee
Sponsor-investigator shall prepare a document describing the scope of duties and operating procedures
Sponsor-investigator may establish an Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee
Sponsor-investigator shall prepare written operating procedures for the Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee
Sponsor-investigator shall prepare and retain records of committee deliberations
Sponsor-investigator shall collect information on quality, efficacy and safety of the trial drug
Sponsor-investigator shall provide collected drug information to the head of the medical institution
Sponsor-investigator shall immediately notify the medical institution head of events specified in Article 80-2
Sponsor-investigator must revise protocol when aware of relevant information
Sponsor-investigator must revise Investigator's Brochure when aware of relevant information
Sponsor-investigator shall prepare written procedures for monitoring
Monitor must conduct monitoring activities in compliance with written procedures
Monitor shall not engage in the clinical trial at the institution being monitored
Monitoring shall be conducted by visiting the medical institution
Monitor must notify investigator if trial non-compliant with regulations or protocol
Monitor shall submit a monitoring report documenting specified information
Monitors must document the date of monitoring after each site visit
Monitors must document their name after each site visit
Monitors must document names of investigators interviewed during the visit
Monitors must summarize the results of the monitoring after each visit
Sponsor-investigators shall prepare an audit plan
Sponsor-investigators shall prepare written operating procedures for audits
Auditors shall not engage in the clinical trial they are auditing
Auditors shall prepare an audit report documenting their findings
Sponsor-investigator shall prematurely terminate the clinical trial if required conditions are met
Sponsor-investigator shall promptly notify medical institution heads in writing of trial suspension or termination
Sponsor-investigator shall provide reasons for trial suspension or termination in writing
Sponsor-investigator shall notify medical institution heads if clinical data will not be submitted for application
Sponsor-investigator shall prepare clinical trial reports upon completion or termination
Sponsor-investigator shall retain clinical trial records for specified time periods
Sponsor-investigators must retain the protocol and approval documents for clinical trials
Sponsor-investigators must retain case report forms from the medical institution
Records of monitoring and audits must be retained
Data generated during the clinical trial must be retained
The head of a medical institution must have an IRB review the clinical trial
The IRB may be established by the medical institution head
The IRB may be established by a General Incorporated Association or Foundation
An IRB may be established by an academic society of healthcare professionals
An Incorporated Educational Institution with a medical institution may establish an IRB
An Incorporated Administrative Agency providing medical care may establish an IRB
An Incorporated National University with a medical institution may establish an IRB
A Local Incorporated Administrative Agency with a medical institution may establish an IRB
The founder of an IRB shall include provisions for IRB establishment in their incorporation articles
The executive directors of an IRB founder shall have authority over the IRB
IRB must include at least one healthcare professional
No more than 1/3 of IRB directors can be employees of a certain medical institution
IRB founder must have sufficient financial basis to establish and operate the IRB
IRB founder shall retain financial documents in office
IRB founder shall provide public access to financial documents
IRB must be capable of reviewing trials from ethical and scientific viewpoints
IRB must be composed of at least five members
IRB must include member(s) without expertise in medicine/healthcare/clinical trials
IRB must include member(s) independent of the medical institution
IRB must include member(s) independent of the IRB founder
IRB founder shall prepare written operating procedures
IRB founder shall disclose operating procedures, member list, and meeting summaries
IRB founder shall appoint person(s) to perform clerical work
IRB members with close ties to sponsor shall not participate in related deliberations
Members who have not participated in the IRB deliberation shall not vote
The head of the medical institution shall seek IRB opinion on trial appropriateness
A written contract must be concluded with external IRBs before review
IRB contracts must specify the date of conclusion
IRB contracts must specify names and addresses of the institution and IRB founder
IRB contracts must specify procedures for contract-related operations
IRB contracts must specify the due date for the IRB opinion
IRB contracts must describe maintaining subject confidentiality
The head of the medical institution may seek opinions from other IRBs on specialized matters
Other IRBs consulted must be specified in Article 27, Paragraph 1
Consulting other IRBs requires agreement from the primary IRB
The head of the medical institution must promptly report opinions from other consulted IRBs
IRBs listed in Items 2-4 of Paragraph 1 must meet requirements in Article 27, Paragraph 2
The head of the medical institution shall conclude a written contract with the expert IRB founder
The IRB contract must specify the date of conclusion
The IRB contract must specify names and addresses of the medical institution and IRB founder
The IRB contract must specify procedures for operations related to the contract
The IRB contract must specify the scope of specialized matters for review and opinion due date
The IRB contract must include a description of maintaining subject confidentiality
Provisions of Article 12, Paragraphs 2 to 5 apply to the IRB contract conclusion
The head of the medical institution shall obtain the IRB's written operating procedures
The head of the medical institution shall obtain the IRB's list of members
The head of the medical institution shall seek the IRB's opinion on continuing the trial annually
Annual IRB review is required when the trial duration exceeds one year
The head of the medical institution shall seek expert IRB opinion on specialized matters
Medical institution head must seek IRB opinion on continuing trial when specified events occur
Medical institution head must seek expert IRB opinion on specialized matters for trial continuation
Provisions of Article 31 Paragraph 5 apply to expert IRB opinions sought under this article
Medical institution head must seek IRB opinion on proper trial conduct after receiving monitoring report
Medical institution head must seek IRB opinion on proper trial conduct after receiving audit report
The IRB shall review the ethical and scientific appropriateness of the clinical trial
The IRB shall review whether it is appropriate to conduct the trial at the medical institution
The IRB shall give its opinion in writing
The IRB shall review documents specified in Article 10, Paragraph 1 or Article 15-7
The IRB shall review documents concerning subject recruitment procedures
The IRB shall review curriculum vitae of each prospective investigator
The expert IRB shall review specialized matters based on necessary documents
The IRB shall review the appropriateness of continuing the clinical trial
Expert IRB shall review specialized matters for determining appropriateness of continuing clinical trial
Each IRB shall provide opinions promptly in writing according to urgency of matters consulted
IRB shall review if clinical trial is being conducted properly at medical institution
IRB shall give opinion in writing on proper conduct of clinical trial
Head of medical institution shall notify sponsor and investigator of IRB opinion in writing
Head of medical institution shall notify sponsor-investigator of IRB opinion in writing
Medical institutions shall not undertake a clinical trial if the IRB deems it inappropriate
Medical institutions shall cancel or terminate trials if the IRB deems continuation inappropriate
The head of the medical institution shall take action if the IRB finds improper trial conduct
The IRB founder shall retain written operating procedures
The IRB founder shall retain a list of IRB members
The IRB founder shall retain records of meetings and summaries
Retain specified documents until 3 years after trial completion or marketing approval
Medical institutions must have facilities for clinical observations and lab tests
Medical institutions must be able to take emergency measures for subjects
Medical institutions must have adequate personnel to conduct the trial
Head of medical institution shall prepare written operating procedures
Head of medical institution shall ensure proper conduct of the trial
The head of the medical institution shall ensure confidentiality of subjects is protected
The head of the medical institution shall cooperate for monitoring conducted by the sponsor
The head of the medical institution shall cooperate for audits conducted by the sponsor
The head of the medical institution shall cooperate for reviews by the IRB
The head of the medical institution shall provide direct access to clinical trial records upon request
The head of the medical institution shall appoint person(s) to perform trial-related clerical work
The investigational product storage manager shall properly control/account for drugs used in clinical trials
The storage manager must comply with operating procedures stipulated in Article 16 or 26-2
Medical institutions must contract with outsourced duty providers via a document specifying required information
Outsourcing contracts must specify the scope of duties outsourced
Outsourcing contracts must describe operating procedures for outsourced duties
Contracts must state the medical institution can verify proper conduct of outsourced duties
Outsourcing contracts must describe instructions to the contractor
Head of medical institution must notify IRB in writing when informed of trial termination by sponsor
Head of medical institution must notify IRB in writing when informed of trial suspension by sponsor
Head of medical institution must notify investigator in writing of trial suspension or termination
Head of medical institution must notify IRB in writing of trial suspension or termination by investigator
Head of medical institution must notify sponsor in writing of trial suspension or termination by investigator
Head of medical institution must notify IRB when informed of trial completion by investigator
Head of medical institution must notify sponsor when informed of trial completion by investigator
The head of the medical institution shall appoint a record keeping manager
The record keeping manager shall retain source documents
The record keeping manager shall retain contracts and Approval Documents
The record keeping manager shall retain informed consent forms
The record keeping manager shall retain the clinical trial protocol
Records must be retained for 3 years after trial completion or drug approval
Maintain records of control and accountability of drugs used in the clinical trial
Investigators must have education, training, and clinical experience to conduct the trial
Investigators shall be well-versed in the trial protocol and Investigator's Brochure
Investigators must have sufficient time to conduct the clinical trial
Prepare a list of duties assigned to subinvestigators and clinical research coordinators
Explain trial duties to subinvestigators and clinical research coordinators
Provide subinvestigators and coordinators with necessary information for their duties
Carefully consider subject's health, symptoms, age, and consent ability for trial objectives
Do not select subjects incapable of consent unless inevitable
Ensure voluntary consent from potentially disadvantaged subjects
Explain appropriate use of trial drugs to each subject
Check if subjects are properly using trial drugs as needed
Inform subject's primary physician of trial participation with consent
Take measures to ensure adequate medical care for adverse events
Inform subjects when medical care is needed for adverse events
Investigators shall conduct the clinical trial in compliance with the IRB-approved protocol
Investigators shall document all deviations from the protocol
Investigators shall immediately submit protocol deviation documents to the sponsor and medical institution head
Investigators shall prepare CRFs accurately in compliance with the protocol
Investigators shall affix their names to CRFs
Changes to CRFs shall be dated and affixed with the investigator's name
Investigators shall inspect and confirm CRFs prepared by subinvestigators
Investigator shall submit written summary of clinical trial status to head of medical institution
Investigator shall immediately report death or serious adverse events to head of medical institution
Investigator shall notify sponsor of death or serious adverse events in sponsor-initiated trials
Investigator shall provide additional information on adverse events upon request
Investigator shall notify other investigators of death/serious events in multi-site investigator-initiated trials
Investigator shall notify investigational product provider of death/serious events in investigator-initiated trials
Investigator shall promptly notify subjects if clinical trial is suspended or terminated
Investigator shall provide appropriate medical care to subjects if trial is suspended/terminated
Investigator shall promptly report trial suspension/termination in writing to head of medical institution
Investigator shall submit written summary of trial outcome upon completion
Investigators shall obtain written informed consent from subjects before trial participation
Investigators shall explain trial information in writing to subjects
Legally acceptable representative may give consent for subjects incapable of consenting
Prepare records of consent from subject's legally acceptable representative
Document relationship of legally acceptable representative to subject
Do not enroll subjects incapable of consent if no clinical benefit is anticipated
Allow prospective subjects to make inquiries about trial information
Answer all subject inquiries to their satisfaction
Provide written information to subjects including specified trial details
Describe alternative procedures or courses of treatment to subjects
Inform subjects of the duration of their participation in the clinical trial
Inform subjects they may withdraw from the clinical trial at any time
Inform subjects that withdrawal does not cause any disadvantage to them
Allow monitors, auditors, and IRB direct access to source documents
Keep subject identity confidential
Provide contact information for trial-related injury to subjects
Informed consent forms must be written in plain language
Investigators and subjects must date and sign the informed consent form
Witnesses must sign informed consent forms when present
Subjects must fully understand the trial content before consenting
Investigators must not coerce subjects to give consent
Investigators must not unduly influence subjects to give consent
Written information must be provided to prospective subjects
Informed consent must be obtained in the presence of a witness for certain subjects
The witness for informed consent must not be an investigator or clinical research coordinator
Investigators must give subjects a copy of their signed informed consent form
Investigators must immediately inform subjects of new information affecting willingness to participate
Investigators must document communication of new information to subjects
Investigators must confirm if subjects will continue participation after receiving new information
Investigators must promptly revise written information when necessary
Investigators must report revisions to written information to the head of the medical institution
Investigators may enroll subjects without consent in emergency life-saving trials if specific conditions are met
The prospective subject must be in an emergency and at obvious life-threatening risk
Currently available treatments must be unlikely to achieve sufficient therapeutic effects for the subject
There must be sufficient possibility of saving the subject's life by using the test drug
Potential disadvantages to the subject in the trial must be minimized
The legally acceptable representative cannot be immediately contacted for consent
Investigators must provide trial information to the subject or representative promptly after emergency enrollment
Written informed consent must be obtained after providing trial information in emergency enrollment cases
Articles 4-6 apply mutatis mutandis to data collection for specified documents
Article 7 (excluding Item 1 of Paragraph 3) applies to data collection for specified documents
Articles 9-15 apply mutatis mutandis to data collection for specified documents
Articles 16-23 apply mutatis mutandis to data collection for specified documents
The term 'clinical trial' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study'
The term 'protocol' shall be read as 'post-marketing protocol'
The term 'investigator' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study investigator'
The term 'coordinating committee' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study coordinating committee'
The term 'subinvestigator' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study subinvestigator'
The term 'sponsor' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study sponsor'
The term 'IRB' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study IRB'
The term 'investigational products' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study drugs'
'All or any of' in Article 7, Paragraph 1, Item (2), shall be read as 'any of'
Post-marketing clinical study drugs must be blinded so investigators cannot distinguish test drug from comparator
Label blinded post-marketing clinical study drugs as 'For post-marketing clinical study use only'
Use 'Approved' instead of 'Proposed' on labels for post-marketing clinical study drugs
Report events specified in Article 68-10, Paragraph 1 of the PMD Act that occur during post-marketing clinical studies
Refer to 'expanded post-marketing clinical study' instead of 'expanded clinical trial'
The 'date of submission' shall be read as the date designated by the Minister when granting marketing approval
'Investigator's Brochure' shall be read as 'instructions for use or Information on Precautions'
'Immediately notify the investigator' shall be read as 'immediately notify the post-marketing clinical study investigator'
'Protocol and Investigator's Brochure' shall be read as 'post-marketing protocol'
Records must be kept for 5 years after completion of reexamination or reevaluation
Retain clinical trial records until completion of reexamination or reevaluation
Rename 'Clinical Trial Office' to 'Post-marketing Clinical Study Office'
Replace 'investigational products' with 'blinded post-marketing clinical study drugs'
Replace 'sponsor' with 'post-marketing clinical study sponsor' in specified sections
Notify when clinical trial data will not be submitted in application
Retain clinical trial records until completion of reexamination or reevaluation
Use post-marketing protocol instead of protocol and Investigator's Brochure
Apply specified provisions mutatis mutandis to standards under PMD Act Article 80-2
Control and account for drugs used in clinical trials
Collect information on adverse drug reactions in clinical trials
Keep records related to clinical trial management
Articles 27-55 apply to persons requested to perform clinical trials

Article 15-7 applies to persons requested to perform clinical trials

Retain quality records for clinical trial materials
This Ministerial Ordinance comes into effect on April 1, 1997
Apply interim measures for documents submitted in product applications
Obtain written informed consent from clinical trial subjects
Obtain informed consent from the subject appropriately

This Ministerial Ordinance shall come into effect from April 1, 2009.
The Ministerial Ordinance shall come into effect from the date of promulgation.
